results.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
results.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

key_work.title: Flipping dress codes and gender expectations
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Both Marlene Dietrich and Billy Porter have used their star personas to transcend the binary and fight for women’s and LGBTQIA+ rights, both on and off the screen.

end.title: Morocco
end.creator_credit: Hector Turnbull, Paramount, Benno Vigny, Josef von Sternberg and Jules Furthman
end.brief_description: The Foreign Legion marches into Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act.

constellations_other.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_other.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

links.description: One of Marlene Dietrich’s iconic white tuxedos is displayed in Goddess. It’s from her personal collection, but she also wore a black one when she shared cinema’s first lesbian kiss in Morocco.

end.title: Victor/Victoria
end.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Tony Adams, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Ladbroke Entertainment
end.brief_description: Sparkling, ultra-sophisticated entertainment from Blake Edwards. This story is based on a 1933 German comedy film “Viktor und Viktoria” written and directed by Rheinhold Schunzel. Set in Paris in 1934, it is the tale of a down-on-her luck chanteuse, played by Julie Andrews. Also suffering a temporary career lapse is tres gai nightclub entertainer (Robert Preston), who remakes her as a man who in short order becomes celebrated as Paris’s foremost female impersonator. In the process she snags the attentions of a Chicago nightclub owner (James Garner). He, however, has a small problem - is it a he or a she who has stolen his heart? 1982 Academy Award for Best Original Score (Henry Mancini). Academy Award nominations for Best Actress (Julie Andrews), Supporting Actor (Robert Preston), Supporting Actress (Lesley Anne Warren), Screenplay Adaptation, Costume Design and Art Direction.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

links.description: The thirties was an exciting time for gender play on screen, from Morocco (1930) to German film Victor/Victoria (1933). Victor/Victoria was remade in English in 1982, starring Julie Andrews as a cisgender woman who poses as a male drag queen, leading to queer romantic confusion.

start.title: The Politician
start.creator_credit: Brad Falchuk Teley-vision, Ryan Murphy Productions and Fox 21 Television Studios
start.brief_description: Payton has known since childhood that he’s going to be president. First he’ll have to navigate the most treacherous political landscape: high school.

end.title: Work in Progress
end.creator_credit: Showtime Networks and Circle of Confusion
end.brief_description: Abby is a 45-year-old self-identified fat, queer dyke whose misfortune and despair unexpectedly lead her to a vibrantly transformative relationship.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

links.description: Unlike their performance in The Politician (2019), Theo Germaine’s role in Work in Progress is deeply invested in trans experience. The series is a love story between two gender non-conforming characters: a trans man called Chris (Germaine) and an older, self-identified fat queer dyke (Abby McEnany), exploring the contours of queer gender dynamics.

start.title: Pose
start.brief_description: A dance musical that explores the juxtaposition of several segments of 1980s life and society in New York: the ball culture world, the rise of the luxury Trump-era universe and the downtown social and literary scene.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

links.description: Pose’s (2018) groundbreaking inclusive casting paved the way for opportunities for trans actors worldwide. In The Politician (2019), trans non-binary actor Theo Germaine was cast as James, a male character whose gender identity is not a feature of his storyline.

start.title: Carlotta
start.creator_credit: David Hannam, Samantha Lang, Murray Picknett, Nicholas Beauman, Story Ark Productions, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Screen NSW
start.brief_description: How many working class Balmain boys grow up to be showgirls? Not just any showgirl but a household name, a legend of Kings Cross, a daytime TV star, and a symbol of generational change.

links.description: Performances like Carlotta’s draw on decades of creative gender performance by Black and Latinx LGBTQIA+ communities. Pose (2018) celebrates New York’s drag and ballroom culture of the 80s and 90s, breaking ground with the largest ever cast of trans actors on a scripted TV show.

links.description: The drag performance in Victor/Victoria (1982) has a local analogue. Carlotta (2014) is based on the life story of legendary trans actress and singer, Carlotta, who came to fame as the star of Sydney cabaret drag act Les Girls, a largely male troupe of ‘female impersonators.’

results.name: Breaking the binary
results.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

key_work.title: Breaking the binary
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: An unexpected mainstream success, Orlando is a landmark work in feminist and LGBTQIA+ cinema, and Swinton’s binary-breaking performance has helped define her persona, allure and influence ever since.

start.brief_description: A crew of savvy former strip club employees band together to turn the tables on their Wall Street clients.

constellations_other.name: Ladies who own the narrative
constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

constellations_other.name: Aquaman VFX
constellations_other.description: As well as becoming a global box-office sensation, Aquaman (2018) featured groundbreaking visual effects from Australian companies such as Method Studios.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Female villains, anti-heroes and scammers
constellations_other.description: Mrs. Appleyard (Natalie Dormer) Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) conceals her dark past by creating a new identity for herself as the Headmistress of the renowned finishing school Appleyard College. Explore how Mrs. Appleyard fits into a cluster of famous female villains and anti-heroes on screen.

end.creator_credit: Sam Feder, Amy Scholder, Fork Films, JustFilms / Ford Foundation, California Humanites, Independent Film Producers (IFP), Sofia Midon, Avram Finklestein, Bow + Arrow Entertainment, Field of Vision and Disclosure Film
end.brief_description: An investigation of how Hollywood’s fabled stories have deeply influenced how Americans feel about transgender people, and how transgender people have been taught to feel about themselves.

constellations_other.description: Documentary Welcome to Chechnya used ground-breaking deep fake technology to hide the identities of LGBTQ+ people fleeing a government-orchestrated genocide in Chechnya.

constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

links.description: Both Zackary Drucker and Tracey Lysette feature in the groundbreaking documentary Disclosure, which takes in-depth look at Hollywood’s depiction of transgender people and the impact of their stories on transgender lives and American culture.

start.brief_description: As influential Italian artist Caravaggio dies in exile in 1610, he recalls his short life, from his childhood to his initial artistic failures to his later triumphs as he catches the eye of a sympathetic cardinal to his destructive relationship with a dashing gambler.

links.description: Swinton’s first film was Caravaggio, made with the Derek Jarman, the English filmmaker, artist, author and gay rights activist. Swinton collaborated with Jarman continuously over the next eight years, appearing in all his subsequent films until his death from AIDS related complications in 1994.

start.brief_description: A darkness swirls at the center of a world-renowned dance company, one that will engulf the troupe’s artistic director, an ambitious young dancer and a grieving psychotherapist. Some will succumb to the nightmare, others will finally wake up.

Argento wasn’t impressed by the remake, saying it “it betrayed the spirit of the original film”.

links.description: In Luca Guadagnino’s Suspiria, Tilda Swinton plays both female and male roles. She was transformed into the 82-year-old male psychoanalyst through prosthetics in a makeup process that took four hours a day. Critics praised Guadagnino for casting a woman as the film’s only significant male role.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: The ‘Breaking the binary’ display in Goddess features the costumes that Tilda Swinton wore in her binary-busting portrayal of the gender-fluid, time-travelling nobleperson. The film was a landmark of LGBTQIA+ 90s cinema and queered the British costume drama.

results.name: Gender avengers
results.description: Thelma and Louise and Promising Young Woman both celebrate women taking revenge on men who sexually assault them, although victory is temporary as the characters perish because of their choices.

key_work.title: Gender avengers
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Both Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman are landmark feminist films that take aim at gender inequality and challenge the patriarchy. Their centring of female friendship, strength and resilience have made them cultural touchstones.

constellations_other.description: Australian born Fearless Nadia would skyrocket to Bollywood fame in her first leading role as Princess Madhuri / the caped crusader herself Hunterwali. Translated in English as a Woman with a whip, Nadia delighted audiences with her daring stunts and circus skills.

start.title: Butterfly Kiss
start.creator_credit: Frank Cottrell Boyce, Michael Winterbottom, Dan Films, British Screen Productions and Merseyside Film Production Fund
start.brief_description: Deeply mentally unbalanced drifter Eunice roams grim northern Britain committing psychosexual serial murders of both men and women while ostensibly searching for an unknown woman named Judith. She spares the life of lonely but kind-hearted gas station cashier Miriam, who abandons her dismal life to follow her damaged new lover. While attempting to hide the evidence of her multiple crimes, Miriam tries to understand Eunice’s bizarre quest.

end.title: The Trip
end.brief_description: Steve agrees to review six restaurants and takes Rob with him.

constellations_other.name: Gender avengers
constellations_other.description: Thelma and Louise and Promising Young Woman both celebrate women taking revenge on men who sexually assault them, although victory is temporary as the characters perish because of their choices.

links.description: For all its gentle humour and vicarious fine dining, The Trip treads a fine line between sending up the egos of Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon’s on-screen personas and reinforcing the misogyny and elitism that drive the characters in Michael Winterbottom’s earlier road movie, Butterfly Kiss, to acts of desperation.

links.description: Butterfly Kiss is a road movie of immense bleakness. Shy Miriam falls for Eunice who seeks release from her psychic pain through violence on the dank highways of northern Britain. As in Thelma and Louise, one world-weary woman enables a more naïve one to find her voice on the road.

constellations_other.name: Big screen dreams
constellations_other.description: With groundbreaking technology and a unique cinema experience, today IMAX theatres are not only loved by audiences but championed by pioneering filmmakers like Christopher Nolan and James Cameron. Yet the route to get there was an unconventional one.

constellations_other.name: Diamonds are still a girl's best friend
constellations_other.description: This constellation explores the continuing cultural impact of Marylin Monroe’s iconic performance of 'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend' in Gentlemen prefer Blondes (1953).

end.title: The Last of Us
end.brief_description: A third person shooter/stealth/survival hybrid, in which twenty years after the outbreak of a parasitic fungus which takes over the neural functions of humans, Joel, a Texan with a tragic familial past, finds himself responsible with smuggling a fourteen year old girl named Ellie to a militia group called the Fireflies, while avoiding strict and deadly authorities, infected fungal hosts and other violent survivors.

constellations_other.name: Gender avengers
constellations_other.description: Thelma and Louise and Promising Young Woman both celebrate women taking revenge on men who sexually assault them, although victory is temporary as the characters perish because of their choices.

constellations_other.name: Representation of women in videogames
constellations_other.description: Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but let's face it – she's just Pac-Man with a bow. This Constellation looks at the history of female representation in videogames.

links.description: Harley Quinn expresses her extreme individuality through her glam grunge outfits, while Ellie from The Last of Us favours survival-grunge jeans and hoodies. Their looks may not have much in common, but Ellie is a rare woman character in a major commercial videogame who isn’t only fully rounded but fully clothed.

links.description: Killing Eve’s sociopathic killer Villanelle (Jodie Comer) dresses in high style – a sign of her independence and confidence. The impossible glamour of the show, like the comic book visual energy of Birds of Prey, are key to understanding the characters, while also signalling both films are elaborate fantasies.

results.name: Writing her own role
results.description: Mae West's signature swagger wasn't only the way she moved but the words she used as the screenwriter of her own dialogue. These stars have also written their own roles.

key_work.title: The sexual gangster
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Throughout her career, Mae West weaponised her words by writing plots that criticised gender conformity and moral hypocrisy. Using witty double entendres and innuendos that were hard to identify in the written script, she flouted the censorship laws of the Hays Code.

start.creator_credit: Fred MacAlpin, Rich Hogan, Tex Avery, Fred Quimby, William Hanna and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
start.brief_description: Tired of always playing the same roles, Little Red Riding Hood, her grandmother and the Wolf demand a new version of the tale. The story then plays out in a more contemperary urban environment, with Little Red Riding Hood working as a pin-up girl in a night club.

end.creator_credit: Dorothy Arzner, Frank Davis, Vicki Baum, Tess Slesinger, Erich Pommer, Edward Stevenson, Robert Wise and RKO Radio Pictures
end.brief_description: Judy O’Brien is an aspiring ballerina in a dance troupe. Also in the company is Bubbles, a brash mantrap who leaves the struggling troupe for a career in burlesque. When the company disbands, Bubbles gives Judy a thankless job as her stooge. The two eventually clash when both fall for the same man.

links.description: Cartoon character Red Hot Riding Hood could have been modelled on burlesque star Bubbles (Lucille Ball) in Dance Girl Dance by pioneering female director Dorothy Arzner. The film contrasts Bubble’s career with that of a serious ballerina played by Maureen O’Hara

results.name: Weaponising glamour
results.description: Josephine Baker wasn't just a star, she was a spy with the French Resistance during the German occupation of France during WWII. She wasn't the only celebrity to weaponise her glamour.

key_work.title: Weaponising glamour
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: When she performed in a risqué skirt of bananas and a beaded necklace in Paris, Josephine Baker became a symbol of the Jazz Age flapper. Her provocative costumes and distinct dancing made her a fashion icon and she was the first African American to lead a feature film, Sirens of the Tropics.

results.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

key_work.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
key_work.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
key_work.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
key_work.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

constellations_other.description: The dawn of the new millennium brought a wave of Australian programming that was more ambitious and bolder than previous decades.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

links.description: Deborah Mailman voices Big Cuz in Little J and Big Cuz. She rose to fame on the Melbourne-set The Secret Life of Us as Kelly Lewis, one of the first Indigenous main characters on a mainstream TV show. Mailman’s performance is considered a landmark in the history of media representations of First Peoples.

end.title: More Than Just a Game
end.creator_credit: Jarra Karalinar Steel
end.material_description: Videogame, arcade machine handcrafted from reclaimed Australian blackwood, LED lettering, custom flooring
end.brief_description:
“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.

constellations_primary.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

links.description: Little J and Big Cuz follows the adventures of First Peoples kids, who haven’t often been represented in Australian screen culture. Jarra Karalinar Steel’s More Than Just a Game follows Dolly, a young Indigenous girl navigating a near-future Melbourne as the hero of a videogame.

start.title: Robbie Hood
start.creator_credit: Since1788 Productions and Ludo Studio
start.brief_description: Joined by his band of merry mates Georgia Blue and Little Johnny, Robbie Hood is a charismatic thirteen-year-old misfit with a heart of gold, who skirts the law to right wrongs he sees playing out in his community. Short of money, and struggling to survive, Robbie and his mates have only themselves to rely on. Guided by the memory of his mother and a strong sense of what’s right and wrong, everything Robbie does is for a reason and, whether good or bad, he does it with the best of intentions. Even if it means helping out his dickhead father.

end.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz

end.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
end.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

links.description: Filmmaker Dylan River drew on his own upbringing in Alice Springs to form the stories in Robbie Hood. His connection to Alice Springs also informed his artwork A Good Eye for Story, displayed in The Story of the Moving Image.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

end.title: Robbie Hood
end.creator_credit: Since1788 Productions and Ludo Studio
end.brief_description: Joined by his band of merry mates Georgia Blue and Little Johnny, Robbie Hood is a charismatic thirteen-year-old misfit with a heart of gold, who skirts the law to right wrongs he sees playing out in his community. Short of money, and struggling to survive, Robbie and his mates have only themselves to rely on. Guided by the memory of his mother and a strong sense of what’s right and wrong, everything Robbie does is for a reason and, whether good or bad, he does it with the best of intentions. Even if it means helping out his dickhead father.

start.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
start.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
start.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
start.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

end.title: Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place
end.creator_credit: Kaylene Whiskey
end.credit_line:
Kaylene Whiskey, Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Lands
Single-channel video, 8 mins
Commissioned by Melbourne Art Foundation in partnership with ACMI
end.brief_description: Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey’s signature pop culture figures fly from the canvas in her latest work, Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place. Whiskey joins them, taking centrestage as a dancing queen with an entourage of seven kungka kunpu (strong women) from her community in Indulkana.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: Two Girls celebrates First Peoples culture and connection to place, particularly Mparntwe (Alice Springs), showing the artists camping and finding bush tucker. Kaylene Whisky’s Ngura Pukulpa - Happy Place similarly uses vibrant animation to celebrate place, her community in Indulkana, and traditional practices.

results.description: Distributed Consciousness mixes NFT technology and custom AI software created by the artist to question artificial intelligence, ecology, sustainability, consciousness and free will - just like the works in this Constellation.

key_work.title: Distributed Consciousness
key_work.credit_line:
Memo Akten

Eight-channel video installation, LED Strips, custom software using Artificial Intelligence, Deep Learning, Generative Adversarial Networks, Transformers, CLIP, VQGAN, GPT3

20 mins
key_work.material_description: Eight-channel video installation, LED Strips, custom software using Artificial Intelligence, Deep Learning, Generative Adversarial Networks, Transformers, CLIP, VQGAN, GPT3
key_work.brief_description: Distributed Consciousness began as an NFT collection on the eco-friendly Tezos blockchain. The 256 images of cephalopods, inspired by the artist’s time spent snorkeling off Turkey’s Mediterranean coastline, were created using custom AI software coded by the artist.
